# Cambridge International AS & A Level  

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[90, 165, 905, 260]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 277, 230, 292]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 278, 904, 292]]<|/det|>
9709/62  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 301, 340, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 6 Probability & Statistics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[770, 302, 904, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[757, 326, 904, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 355, 393, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[93, 384, 392, 399]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 434, 880, 636]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 664, 212, 678]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 680, 728, 711]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 72, 149, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 72, 616, 88]]<|/det|>
One of a group of three students is to be chosen at random.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 816, 120]]<|/det|>
Explain how a single throw of a fair six-sided dice could be used to make the choice. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 225, 918, 259]]<|/det|>
<pre>The times, in minutes, taken by students to complete a test are normally distributed with mean 125 and variance 50. Two students are chosen at random.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 273, 146, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 273, 918, 305]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the difference between the times taken by these two students to complete the test is more than 12 minutes. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 915, 336]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 104]]<|/det|>
The height of a certain species of plant is denoted by \(H\mathrm{cm}.\) The heights of a random sample of 100 plants were measured, and the following results were found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 120, 460, 135]]<|/det|>
• The mean, \(\overline{h}\) , for the sample was 80.2.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 135, 651, 150]]<|/det|>
• An unbiased estimate of the population variance of \(H\) was 15.6.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 165, 332, 181]]<|/det|>
Calculate the value of \(\Sigma h^2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 165, 920, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 73, 520, 90]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{Po}(15)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 584, 122]]<|/det|>
Write down an expression in terms of e for \(\mathrm{P}(X = 12)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 197, 440, 215]]<|/det|>
<pre>It is given that \(\mathrm{P}(X = n) = \mathrm{P}(X = n + 1)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 230, 146, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 230, 620, 247]]<|/det|>
Write down an equation in \(n\), and hence find the value of \(n\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 230, 920, 247]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 260, 917, 938]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 87]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 918, 151]]<|/det|>
A biased spinner has four sides. Each side is of a different colour: yellow, red, green or black. The probability, \(p\) , that the spinner will land on red is unknown. The spinner was spun 200 times, and the proportion, \(a\) , of times that it landed on red was noted. This proportion was used to calculate an approximate \(90\%\) confidence interval for \(p\). The width of this confidence interval was 0.1066 correct to 4 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 165, 383, 182]]<|/det|>
Find the two possible values of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 918, 182]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 72, 918, 153]]<|/det|>
The amount of time, in minutes, spent by a customer on one visit to a certain shop is modelled by the random variable \(X \sim \mathrm{N}(\mu , \sigma^2)\). In the past, the values of \(\mu\) and \(\sigma\) were 10.5 and 3.8 respectively. The shop has recently moved to a new location, and the manager hopes that the new value of \(\mu\) will be greater than 10.5. He takes a random sample of 10 customers and notes the time they each spend in the shop. He then calculates the sample mean \(\overline{x}\) for these 10 times.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 165, 918, 198]]<|/det|>
Using a hypothesis test at the \(5\%\) significance level, the manager finds that there is sufficient evidence to conclude that the new value of \(\mu\) is greater than 10.5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 211, 660, 228]]<|/det|>
Stating a necessary assumption, find the smallest possible value of \(\overline{x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 211, 918, 228]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 630, 90]]<|/det|>
Use suitable approximating distributions to answer the following.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 146, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 103, 618, 121]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(W\) has the distribution \(\mathrm{B}(700, 0.005)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 133, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 171, 153]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 135, 322, 153]]<|/det|>
Find \(\mathrm{P}(W \geqslant 4)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 165, 917, 432]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 465, 462]]<|/det|>
Two values of \(W\) are chosen at random.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 476, 180, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 475, 715, 494]]<|/det|>
Find the probability that the sum of these two values is less than 3.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 475, 920, 494]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 505, 917, 925]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 568, 90]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has the distribution \(\text{Po}(200)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 104, 641, 122]]<|/det|>
Use a suitable approximating distribution to find \(\text{P}(X > 205)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 918, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 135, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 623, 90]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(X\) has probability density function given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[378, 104, 620, 168]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}kx^2 & 0\leqslant x\leqslant a,\\ a^2 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 178, 405, 195]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) and \(a\) are positive constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 215, 146, 233]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 212, 295, 235]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{3}{a}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 214, 917, 233]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 242, 917, 515]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 524, 314, 542]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\mathrm{E}(X) = 1.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 555, 148, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 555, 310, 573]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 555, 918, 573]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 585, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
Birgitte has a six-sided dice. She suspects that the dice is biased so that the probability, \(p\) , that it will show a six on one throw is less than \(\frac{1}{6}\) . She throws the dice 30 times and finds that it shows a six on exactly 2 throws.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 136, 148, 154]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 135, 806, 153]]<|/det|>
Use a binomial distribution with a \(5\%\) significance level to test Birgitte's suspicion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 135, 920, 154]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 917, 945]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 72, 918, 88]]<|/det|>
<pre>Later, Birgitte carries out a similar test at the \(5\%\) significance level, using another 30 throws of the dice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 485, 120]]<|/det|>
Calculate the probability of a Type I error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 918, 120]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 917, 432]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 444, 144, 462]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 444, 813, 462]]<|/det|>
Given that the value of \(p\) is actually 0.02, calculate the probability of a Type II error.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 462]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 476, 917, 925]]<|/det|>
